title: Eid al-Fitr
short_description: The joyful Festival of Breaking the Fast, marked by communal prayers, rich feasts, and the spirit of charity.
long_description:
Eid al-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the holy month of fasting. It is a day of immense joy, thanksgiving, and community. The day begins with the sighting of the new moon, signaling the start of the Shawwal month. In the morning, thousands of Muslim men dressed in blinding white kurtas gather at mosques (Idgahs) for a special congregational prayer—a synchronized display of faith that is moving to witness.

After prayers, the streets come alive. People embrace three times in the traditional 'Eid Mubarak' greeting. The air fills with the aroma of 'Sewiyan' (sweet vermicelli pudding) and slow-cooked Biryani. It is a day of breaking barriers; non-Muslim friends and neighbors are invited to feasting tables. Charity (Zakat al-Fitr) is a mandatory pillar, ensuring even the poor can celebrate. In cities like Delhi and Hyderabad, the festive food walks around the mosques are legendary.
significance: Celebrates the conclusion of the dawn-to-sunset fasting during Ramadan.
key_rituals: Eid Namaz: The special morning community prayer.
Zakat al-Fitr: Giving charity to the poor before the prayer.
Sheer Khurma: Preparing the traditional date and vermicelli milk pudding.
Eidi: Giving money or gifts to children and younger relatives.

practical_info.dress_tips: Modest clothing is essential. Women should cover heads when entering mosque areas (though prayer halls may be restricted).
practical_info.safety_tips: Old city areas become extremely crowded. Keep valuables safe.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Mosques usually have steps; access may be limited.

faqs.q: Can tourists visit mosques during prayer?
faqs.a: Usually, tourists are not allowed inside the main prayer hall during the Eid Namaz itself, but can watch from the perimeter. Visiting after the prayer is fine.
Haleem (meat stew) and Sheer Khurma (sweet pudding) are the festival signatures.
